column1: Schiedam ([sxiˈdɑm] (listen)) is a city and municipality in the west of the Netherlands. It is located in the Rotterdam–The Hague metropolitan area
column4: and south of Delft. In the south the city is connected with the village of Pernis by the Beneluxtunnel.

column1: The city is known for its historical center with canals
column2: and for having the tallest windmills in the world. Schiedam is also well known for the distilleries and malthouses and production of jenever (gin) − such as the internationally renowned Ketel One − so much so that in French and English the word schiedam (usually without a capital s-) refers to the town's Holland gin. This was the town's main industry during the early Industrial Revolution in the 18th and 19th century
column3: a dark period to which it owed its former nickname "Zwart Nazareth" or "Black Nazareth". Furthermore
column4: the city is known for Saint Lidwina
column5: one of the most famous Dutch saints (her relics are located in the Liduina Basilica in Schiedam).

column1: == History ==
Schiedam was founded in Rotterdam; around the year 1230 the river Schie was dammed by the Lord of Wassenaer and the Amtlord Dirk Bokel of the Amt Mathenesse
column2: this to protect the existing polderland against the seawater from the North Sea. In 1247
column3: Lady Adelaide (Aleida) of Holland married John I
column4: Count of Hainaut. As dowry she received from him the eastern part of the dam together with the adjacent polder. The dam attracted many trade activities because goods for and from the hinterland (Delft
column5: and further away Leiden and Haarlem) had to be transhipped. A small town developed swiftly around the dam and its activities. In the year 1275 Schiedam received city rights from Lady Adelaide
column6: this in her capacity as sister of William II
column7: the reigning Count of Holland and becoming King of the Romans. She ordered the building of a castle near the Schie
column8: which is known till today as the "Castle Mathenesse" (Dutch: "Huis te Riviere" or "Slot Mathenesse"). Remnants of a donjon
column9: which were once part of the castle
column10: are still visible today in the centre of Schiedam and near the city office.

column1: As a young settlement Schiedam soon got competition from surrounding towns and cities: in 1340
column2: Rotterdam and Delft also were allowed to establish a connection between the Schie and the Meuse. From the 15th century on the city flourished as a place of pilgrimage on the devotion around Saint Lidwina
column3: one of the most famous Dutch saints who lived her life in Schiedam. The city gained subsequently significance by fishing for herring. In 1428 a great city fire swept through Schiedam
column4: thereby destroying large parts of the then wooden city .

column1: The 18th century was Schiedam's Golden Age
column2: when the gin industry flourished. The standstill drink imports from France made the emergence of the Schiedamse distillery possible. From dozens of distilleries Schiedam jenever was exported throughout the world. The gin industry gave the city its nickname 'Black Nazareth'. This industry is now largely gone. Five windmills in the town
column6: Nieuwe Palmboom and Vrijheid − are the highest traditional style windmills in the world because they had to stick out above the high warehouses
column7: and many storehouses are relics of this past. In one of the former factories at the Lange Haven the National Jenever Museum is established.

column1: On 10 August 1856 the first major train accident in the Netherlands happened near the Schiedam railway station
column2: causing 3 deaths. On 4 May 1976 the Schiedam train disaster also took place near the station which caused 24 deaths.At the end of the 19th and throughout the 20th century
column3: the shipbuilding industry was booming in Schiedam
column4: with the existence of large companies like Wilton-Fijenoord and others. In 1941
column5: the ancient municipalities Kethel en Spaland were merged with Schiedam which made large expansions of the city possible with residential areas in the north. At the end of the 20th century the shipbuilding industry largely disappeared and nowadays Schiedam is mainly a commuter town being part of the Rotterdam metropolitan area.

column1: == Geography ==
The city of Schiedam is located in the Dutch province of South Holland. It is enclosed between Rotterdam (east)
column3: Vlaardingen (west) and the river Nieuwe Maas (south).

== Sport ==
The most popular sports in Schiedam are soccer and field hockey. The town used to have a professional soccer team named svv (Schiedamse voetbal vereniging)
column2: but after financial problems the club was declared bankrupt. Cricket is more popular in Schiedam than in most other Dutch cities.
